'''Kendall''' is a [[suburb]]an [[neighborhoods of Miami-Dade County|neighborhood]] of [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|metropolitan]] [[Miami]], [[Florida]], [[United States]]. As of the [[United States Census 2000|2000 census]], the area had a total population of 75,226.
While the defined boundaries of the community have been labeled Kendall by the US Census Bureau, locals often included western communities, such as [[The Hammocks, Florida|The Hammocks]], [[Country Walk, Florida|Country Walk]], [[The Crossings, Florida|The Crossings]], [[Kendale Lakes, Florida|Kendale Lakes]], [[Kendall West, Florida|Kendall West]], and [[Three Lakes, Florida|Three Lakes]], [[subdivision (land)|subdivision]]s of Kendall. According to the census, Kendall is home to over 11,000 [[Colombian American]]s, one of the largest populations in the United States.
Kendall is served by the [[Metrorail (Miami)|Miami Metrorail]] at [[Dadeland North (Metrorail station)|Dadeland North]] and [[Dadeland South (Metrorail station)|Dadeland South]] stations. Both stations provide service from [[Dadeland, Florida|Dadeland]] to [[Downtown Miami]], and [[Miami Central Station]] at [[Miami International Airport]] in [[2012 in rail transport|2012]]. Dadeland South station is a major transit depot in the area, connecting the southernmost suburbs of [[Homestead, Florida|Homestead]] and [[Florida City, Florida|Florida City]] to Metrorail via [[limited-stop]] [[bus rapid transit]] along the [[Miami-Dade Transit#South Miami-Dade Busway|South Miami-Dade Busway]].
==History== Much of what is now Kendall was purchased from the State of Florida in 1883 by the Florida Land and Mortgage Company. It is named after Henry John Broughton Kendall, a [[Board of directors|director]] of the company who moved to the area in the 1900s to manage the company's land. As the land was not open to [[Homestead Act|homesteading]], development was slow well into the 20th century. A post office opened in 1914, and the first school opened in 1929. After the end of the [[Florida land boom of the 1920s|land boom]] in 1926, some residents left. Two [[Seminole]] camps were in the Kendall area, and Seminoles continued to live there into the 1940s.<ref>Taylor, Jean. (1986) ''Villages of South Dade''. St. Petersburg, Florida: Byron Kennedy and Company. ISBN 0-041072-12-6 Pp. 39â49.</ref>
==Geography== Kendall is located at {{Coord|25|40|0|N|80|21|24|W|type:city}} (25.666781, -80.356533){{GR|1}}.
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the Kendall region has an approximate total area of 42.3 kmÂ² (16.3 miÂ²). 41.8 kmÂ² (16.1 miÂ²) of it is land and 0.6 kmÂ² (0.2 miÂ²) of it (1.35%) is water.
==Climate== Climate in Kendall is naturally similar to the remainder of [[Miami-Dade County]], although its location and elevation inland along the [[Miami Rock Ridge]] does make it slightly cooler at night during the winter and slightly warmer during the day in the summer.

==Demographics== {{USCensusPop | 1970=35497 | 1980=73758 | 1990=87271 | 2000=75226 | 2010=75371 | footnote=source:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.census.gov/prod/www/abs/decennial/index.html |title=CENSUS OF POPULATION AND HOUSING (1790â2000) |publisher=[[U.S. Census Bureau]] |accessdate=2010-07-17}}</ref><ref>Kendall lost census territory when [[Pinecrest, Florida|Pinecrest]] incorporated in 1996.</ref> }}
{| id="toc" style="float: left; margin-right: 2em; width: 39%; font-size: 75%;" cellspacing="3" !colspan="3"|'''Kendall Demographics''' |- |'''[[United States Census, 2010|2010 Census]]'''||'''Kendall'''||'''Miami-Dade County'''||'''Florida''' |- |Total population||75,371||2,496,435||18,801,310 |- |Population, percent change, 2000 to 2010||+0.2%||+10.8%||+17.6% |- |Population density||4,687.2/sq mi||1,315.5/sq mi||350.6/sq mi |- |[[White (U.S. Census)|White or Caucasian]] (including [[White Hispanic]])||87.9%||73.8%||75.0% |- |([[Non-Hispanic Whites|Non-Hispanic White or Caucasian]])||28.4%||15.4%||57.9% |- |[[Black (U.S. Census)|Black or African-American]]||4.4%||18.9%||16.0% |- |[[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic or Latino (of any race)]]||63.7%||65.0%||22.5% |- |[[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]]||3.0%||1.5%||2.4% |- |[[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]] or [[Native Alaskan]]||0.1%||0.2%||0.4% |- |[[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]] or [[Native Hawaiian]]||0.0%||0.0%||0.1% |- |[[Multiracial American|Two or more races (Multiracial)]]||2.2%||2.4%||2.5% |- |[[Other races|Some Other Race]]||2.4%||3.2%||3.6% |}
As of 2010, there were 31,899 households, and 8.7% were vacant. As of 2000, 33.4% households had children under the age of 18 living with them, 51.0% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 13.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 31.0% were non-families. 24.4% of all households were made up of individuals and 7.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.61 and the average family size was 3.14.
In 2000, the region's population was spread out with 23.3% under the age of 18, 8.6% from 18 to 24, 31.8% from 25 to 44, 24.9% from 45 to 64, and 11.5% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 37 years. For every 100 females there were 88.5 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 83.4 males.
In 2000, the median income for a household in the area was $51,330, and the median income for a family was $61,241. Males had a median income of $42,875 versus $31,416 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the area was $27,914. About 5.7% of families and 8.6% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 8.0% of those under age 18 and 10.9% of those age 65 or over.
As of 2000, speakers of [[Spanish language|Spanish]] as a [[first language]] accounted for 52.46% of all residents, while [[English language|English]] speakers comprised 40.38%, [[Brazilian Portuguese|Portuguese]] was 1.49%, [[French language|French]] at 1.12%, and [[Haitian Creole|French Creole]] made up 0.95% of the population.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mla.org/map_data_results&state_id=12&county_id=&mode=&zip=&place_id=36100&cty_id=&ll=&a=&ea=&order=r |title=MLA Data Center Results of Kendall, FL |publisher=[[Modern Language Association]] |accessdate=2007-11-06}}</ref>
As of 2000, Kendall had the twenty-first highest percentage of [[Cuba]]n residents in the US, with 21.31% of the populace.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epodunk.com/ancestry/Cuban.html |title=Ancestry Map of Cuban Communities |publisher=Epodunk.com |accessdate=2007-11-06}}</ref> It had the twenty-fifth highest percentage of [[Colombia]]n residents in the US, at 4.56% of the population,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epodunk.com/ancestry/Colombian.html |title=Ancestry Map of Colombian Communities |publisher=Epodunk.com |accessdate=2007-11-06}}</ref> and the sixteenth highest percentage of [[Nicaragua]]n residents in the US, at 2.48% of its population.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epodunk.com/ancestry/Nicaraguan.html |title=Ancestry Map of Nicaraguan Communities |publisher=Epodunk.com |accessdate=2007-11-06}}</ref> It also had the twenty-fifth most [[Peru]]vians in the US, at 2.01% (tied with [[Carteret, New Jersey]],)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epodunk.com/ancestry/Peruvian.html |title=Ancestry Map of Peruvian Communities |publisher=Epodunk.com |accessdate=2007-11-06}}</ref> while it had the tenth highest percentage of [[Venezuela]]n residents in the US, at 1.47% of the population.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epodunk.com/ancestry/Venezuelan.html |title=Ancestry Map of Venezuelan Communities |publisher=Epodunk.com |accessdate=2007-11-06}}</ref> As a result of the city's large French community, the French American School of Miami is located in Kendall. It is the only French American school in the southern United States.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}}
==Media== West Kendall is served by the Miami market for local [[Template:Miami Radio|radio]] and [[Template:Miami TV|television]]. Kendall has its own newspaper, ''The Kendall Gazette'', which is published twice monthly and is part of [[Miami's Community Newspapers]], the "Voice of the Community".
==Transportation== Kendall is served by [[Miami-Dade Transit#Metrobus|Metrobus]] throughout the area, and by the [[Metrorail (Miami)|Metrorail]] at:
*{{color box|#{{MDM color|Green}}}} [[Dadeland North (Metrorail station)|Dadeland North]] (SW 70th Avenue and U.S. 1) *{{color box|#{{MDM color|Green}}}} [[Dadeland South (Metrorail station)|Dadeland South]] (Dadeland Boulevard and U.S. 1)
==Economy== [[Pollo Tropical]] has its headquarters in Kendall.<ref name="KendallMap">"[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/MapItDrawServlet?geo_id=16000US1236100&_bucket_id=50&tree_id=420&context=saff&_lang=en&_sse=on Kendall CDP, Florida]." ''[[U.S. Census Bureau]]''. Retrieved on June 17, 2009.</ref><ref>"[http://www.pollotropical.com/PDFS/20090511_1.pdf POLLO TROPICAL SIZZLES UP HOT NEW CARIBBEAN CHICKEN FAJITAS AT AN UNBEATABLE $5.99]." [[Pollo Tropical]]. May 18, 2009. Retrieved on January 9, 2010.</ref>
Prior to its dissolution [[Air Florida]] was headquartered in the Dade Towers in what is now the Kendall CDP.<ref name="KendallMap"/><ref>''World Airline Directory''. Flight International. March 20, 1975. "[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1975/1975%20-%200530.html 466].</ref>
==Government and infrastructure== The [[Miami-Dade Police Department]] operates the Kendall District Station in the CDP.<ref name="KendallMap"/><ref>"[http://www.miamidade.gov/mdpd/stations/station_Kendall_5.asp Kendall District Station]." [[Miami-Dade Police Department]]. Retrieved on March 12, 2010.</ref>
==Notable residents== *[[Janet Reno]]<ref>Malcolm, Andrew. "[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/06/janet-reno-alonz-mourning.html Janet Reno to be named for Alonzo Mourning or something like that]." ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. June 17, 2009. Retrieved on June 17, 2009.</ref> *[[OJ Simpson]]<ref>"[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/1615527.stm OJ Simpson cleared of 'road rage']." ''[[BBC]]''. Wednesday October 21, 2001. Retrieved on June 17, 2009.</ref>
==Education== ===Primary and secondary schools=== ====Public schools==== The first public school in Kendall was Kendall School, now renamed Kenwood K-8 Center. Kenwood is the site of the Kenwoods Hammock, a native forest planting which has become a world-renowned stop for bird watchers.
[[Miami-Dade County Public Schools]] serves Kendall.
